articles.headline: Entrepreneurs From China Flourish in Africa
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of Chinese migrants are doing business on a continent that until five years or so ago had been terra incognita.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Chinese migrants are doing business on a continent that until five years or so ago had been terra incognita.
articles.lead_paragraph: LILONGWE, Malawi — When Yang Jie left home at 18, he was doing what people from China’s hardscrabble Fujian Province have done for generations: emigrating in search of a better living overseas.
articles.byline: By Howard W. French and Lydia Polgreen

articles.headline: What a Difference a Simple Rate Cut Makes
articles.snippet: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 233 points Friday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates for loans to banks and indicated it would act again if the economic outlook worsens.
articles.abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 233 points Friday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates for loans to banks and indicated it would act again if the economic outlook worsens.
articles.lead_paragraph: As they have so often in the last few weeks, Wall Street traders came to work yesterday braced for the worst. Stock markets in Asia had taken a blow overnight. There was talk that the nation’s biggest home lender might be facing bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Padilla Case Offers New Model of Terrorism Trial
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s use of a seldom-tested conspiracy law in the case  cemented a new prosecutorial paradigm.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s use of a seldom-tested conspiracy law in the case  cemented a new prosecutorial paradigm.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were two perfectly predictable schools of thought being expressed after the conviction of Jose Padilla on Thursday on terrorism-related charges. Supporters of the Bush administration said the conviction justified the more than three years Mr. Padilla spent in military detention before his criminal prosecution, while the administration’s opponents said the verdict proved that the criminal justice system should have handled the case in the first place.

articles.headline: Markets Quake, and a ‘Neutral’ Strategy Slips
articles.snippet: In this month’s market turbulence, even quantitative investing systems, managed by computers, have faltered.
articles.abstract: In this month’s market turbulence, even quantitative investing systems, managed by computers, have faltered.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We have to atone to our clients, but we have no right to whine for ourselves,” said Clifford Asness, the co-founder of AQR Capital Management, a money management firm that has been much in the news recently. “When we succeed, we make a boatload of money, we get imitators, and our risk increases. That’s how capitalism works.”

articles.headline: The Fed’s Sudden Action Eases a Logjam in Corporate Borrowing
articles.snippet: Corporate short-term borrowing seized up this week as investors became nervous at the prospect that many of those notes were backed by subprime mortgages, but the Fed’s action on Friday helped ease concerns.
articles.abstract: Corporate short-term borrowing seized up this week as investors became nervous at the prospect that many of those notes were backed by subprime mortgages, but the Fed’s action on Friday helped ease concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Board’s move yesterday to stabilize the credit markets helped to ease the pressure on a mundane but crucial part of the financial markets: short-term lending to corporations.

articles.headline: Utah Mine Rescuers Halt Search After 3 Deaths
articles.snippet: A sense of doleful finality has settled over the quivering mountain that swallowed six miners 11 days ago.
articles.abstract: A sense of doleful finality has settled over the quivering mountain that swallowed six miners 11 days ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 17 — A sense of doleful finality settled on Friday over the quivering mountain here that swallowed six coal miners 11 days ago.
articles.byline: By Dan Frosch and N. R. Kleinfield

articles.headline: Fearing Slide in Economy, Fed Cuts Its Discount Rate
articles.snippet: The rare move was seen as an admission by the Federal Reserve that its outlook on the credit crisis was flawed, and analysts suggested that further cuts are likely.
articles.abstract: The rare move was seen as an admission by the Federal Reserve that its outlook on the credit crisis was flawed, and analysts suggested that further cuts are likely.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve, saying for the first time that the recent disorder in the financial markets has raised the risk of an economic downturn, took the unusual step yesterday of encouraging the nation’s banks to borrow directly from the Fed, particularly to support home mortgage lending.

articles.headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Stops Selling Lead-Tainted Bibs
articles.snippet: The giant toy chain said Friday that it would halt sales of vinyl baby bibs after tests it commissioned in recent days found two samples with lead exceeding its standards.
articles.abstract: The giant toy chain said Friday that it would halt sales of vinyl baby bibs after tests it commissioned in recent days found two samples with lead exceeding its standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toys “R” Us halted the sale of vinyl baby bibs at its stores nationwide yesterday and offered customers refunds on perhaps more than a million bibs after tests confirmed that at least some of the Chinese-made items are contaminated with lead.

articles.headline: Being Right Is Bittersweet for a Critic of Lenders
articles.snippet: For more than a decade, Edward M. Gramlich, a Federal Reserve Board governor, has been warning of dangers in the housing market. But now, he’s fighting for his life.
articles.abstract: For more than a decade, Edward M. Gramlich, a Federal Reserve Board governor, has been warning of dangers in the housing market. But now, he’s fighting for his life.
articles.lead_paragraph: This should have been Edward M. Gramlich’s moment.

articles.headline: Falluja’s Calm Is Seen as Fragile if U.S. Leaves
articles.snippet: Western Iraq’s improved security, often cited as a success story, could be undermined as the Marines withdraw.
articles.abstract: Western Iraq’s improved security, often cited as a success story, could be undermined as the Marines withdraw.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq — Falluja’s police chief, Col. Faisal Ismail Hussein, waved aloft a picture of a severed head in a bucket as a reminder of the brutality of the fundamentalist Sunni militias that once controlled this city. But he also described an uncertain future without “my only supporters,” the United States Marine Corps.

articles.headline: A Hotelier Is Breaking the Mold Once Again
articles.snippet: With Marriott as a partner, Ian Schrager, the master of the ultrahip hotel, hopes to expand his vision.
articles.abstract: With Marriott as a partner, Ian Schrager, the master of the ultrahip hotel, hopes to expand his vision.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the world according to Ian Schrager, the master of the ultrahip hotel, there’s no greater currency than a boldface name checking into a stylish guest room or hanging out in the chic bar or restaurant. Mr. Schrager cut his teeth among the in-crowd in the late 1970s and early ’80s, as co-founder of the Studio 54 and Palladium nightclubs in New York City, and has since courted the slender, fashionable and martini-prone with such gusto — from the Royalton and Paramount hotels in Manhattan to the Delano in South Beach and the Mondrian in West Hollywood — that he has earned rock-star status of his own.

articles.headline: Funds Stopped Playing Before the Game Got Ugly
articles.snippet: Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of Grand Theft Auto, was alerted to a possible enforcement action after announcing its new game would be delayed.
articles.abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of Grand Theft Auto, was alerted to a possible enforcement action after announcing its new game would be delayed.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAKE-TWO INTERACTIVE SOFTWARE, the maker of Grand Theft Auto, the shoot-’em-up video game, disclosed last week that it had received a Wells notice on Aug. 9 from the Securities and Exchange Commission, alerting the company to a possible enforcement action.

articles.headline: Loan by Loan, the Making of a Credit Squeeze
articles.snippet: About 1.7 million households will lose their homes to foreclosure this year and next, according to estimates, nearly double the number of the previous two years.
articles.abstract: About 1.7 million households will lose their homes to foreclosure this year and next, according to estimates, nearly double the number of the previous two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: THREE years ago, Martin and Jennifer Cossette bought into the dream of homeownership — the quintessentially American ideal of personal striving and family stability celebrated by politicians, promoted by Madison Avenue and financed by Wall Street.

articles.headline: How Missed Signs Contributed to a Mortgage Meltdown
articles.snippet: There were ample warning signs that a financial time bomb in the form of subprime mortgages was ticking quietly for months.
articles.abstract: There were ample warning signs that a financial time bomb in the form of subprime mortgages was ticking quietly for months.
articles.lead_paragraph: All through last year, Jim Melcher saw the signs of a rapidly deteriorating American housing market — riskier mortgages, rising delinquencies and more homes falling into foreclosure. And with $100 million in assets at his hedge fund, Balestra Capital, he was in a position to do something about it.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Seeing Corporate Fingerprints in Wikipedia Edits
articles.snippet: A new Web site reveals that many of the most obviously self-interested changes come from corporate networks.
articles.abstract: A new Web site reveals that many of the most obviously self-interested changes come from corporate networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year a Wikipedia visitor edited the entry for the SeaWorld theme parks to change all mentions of “orcas” to “killer whales,” insisting that this was a more accurate name for the species.

articles.headline: Move Over Mickey: A New Franchise at Disney
articles.snippet: The debut of “High School Musical 2” was the most watched show among children 6 to 11 and 9 to 14 in basic cable history, estimates show.
articles.abstract: The debut of “High School Musical 2” was the most watched show among children 6 to 11 and 9 to 14 in basic cable history, estimates show.
articles.lead_paragraph: When “High School Musical 2,” the sequel to the hit 2006 made-for-television movie, made its debut on the Disney Channel on Friday night, it was a highly anticipated moment for millions of children across the nation.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Are Squeezed by Investors and Lenders
articles.snippet: As problems in subprime mortgage lending have expanded into the broader markets, hedge funds have come face to face with the ghost of past financial crises.
articles.abstract: As problems in subprime mortgage lending have expanded into the broader markets, hedge funds have come face to face with the ghost of past financial crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: As summer neared, investors in Sowood Capital Management, a $3 billion hedge fund, had little to complain about.

articles.headline: Ad Growth for AOL Called Vital to a Remake
articles.snippet: A precipitous slowdown in advertising growth has raised new questions about AOL’s transformation plans.
articles.abstract: A precipitous slowdown in advertising growth has raised new questions about AOL’s transformation plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 — Just over a year ago, AOL unveiled a radical plan to remake itself into a business built on advertising from one driven by Internet access subscriptions.

articles.headline: After Foreclosure, a Big Tax Bill From the I.R.S.
articles.snippet: Americans who have lost their homes may be subject to income taxes on their canceled debt.
articles.abstract: Americans who have lost their homes may be subject to income taxes on their canceled debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, William Stout lost his home in Allentown, Pa., to foreclosure when he could no longer make the payments on his $106,000 mortgage. Wells Fargo offered the two-bedroom house for sale on the courthouse steps. No bidders came forward. So Wells Fargo bought it for $1, county records show.

articles.headline: How Solid Is the Deal for Tribune Company?
articles.snippet: When shareholders gather to approve an $8.2 billion plan to take Tribune private, an uncomfortable question is sure to be on many of their minds: Will this deal fall apart?
articles.abstract: When shareholders gather to approve an $8.2 billion plan to take Tribune private, an uncomfortable question is sure to be on many of their minds: Will this deal fall apart?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tribune Company shareholders gather tomorrow in Chicago to approve an $8.2 billion plan to take the company private, an uncomfortable question is sure to be on many of their minds: Will this deal fall apart?

articles.headline: Rising Breed of Migrant: Skilled and Welcome
articles.snippet: As legions of workers across the globe face new barriers to migration, professionals find more welcome mats.
articles.abstract: As legions of workers across the globe face new barriers to migration, professionals find more welcome mats.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHARJAH, United Arab Emirates — In this country where foreigners do most of the work, there are migrant maids and migrant masons, migrant tea boys and migrant typists, all doing what most migrant laborers do, menial tasks for meager wages.

articles.headline: To Compete With E-Mail Greetings, Funny Cards Try to Be Topical
articles.snippet: Greeting card companies hope to promote the idea that cards can be sent anytime, not just on holidays and special occasions.
articles.abstract: Greeting card companies hope to promote the idea that cards can be sent anytime, not just on holidays and special occasions.
articles.lead_paragraph: “How can a working mom get 8 hours sleep?” is the question on the cover of a greeting card newly on the store racks.

articles.headline: In First Crisis on the Job, Bernanke’s About-Face Is Weighed
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke, grappling with his first major predicament as Fed chairman, is being intently watched to see how he handles the reins of the economy.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, grappling with his first major predicament as Fed chairman, is being intently watched to see how he handles the reins of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 — For the last month, the stock market has gyrated as every other day seemed to bring more bad news about the housing and credit markets. Traders awaited a signal from the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, now in his sophomore year at the helm of the central bank.
